data.title: Al Pacino's Lost Roles
data.meta_description: Michael Corleone as Han Solo? A look back at the many iconic roles that couldâve been for Oscar-winning actor Al Pacino.
data.text:
Though heâs often been called one of the greatest actors of his generation, Al Pacino will no doubt be remembered as one of the greatest actors of all time. After making his movie debut opposite Patty Duke in 1969âs Me, Natalie, Pacino would go on to become one of the most seminal figures in the âNew Hollywoodâ movement of the 1970s (the pre-blockbuster era in which the counterculture became the mainstream) with starring roles in The Godfather trilogy, Scarecrow, Serpico, Dog Day Afternoon, Bobby Deerfield, and â¦And Justice for All.

Though heâs racked up more than 50 credits in his 50-year career, Pacino has also turned down plenty of roles (including several in truly great movies). When asked about his track record for saying no in 2013, Pacino explained, âIâm not a very good judge of whatâs good.â Here are 16 roles that could have been.

1. The Gang That Couldn't Shoot Straight (1971)

Super-producer Robert Evans needed to call in a lot of favors to get Pacino out of the commitment he had made to playing Mario in James Goldstoneâs Mafia comedy. The reason for the change of heart? Two days after agreeing to the part, he was offered the role of Michael Corleone. Eventually, Robert De Niro played the part that was meant for Pacino.

2. Lenny (1974)

In 2010, Pacino told Larry King that turning down the title role in Bob Fosseâs Lenny Bruce biopic is one of his biggest regrets. Though he didnât originally think it was for him, after seeing a comic perform live, âI suddenly saw what I would want to do with this part.â At that point, it was too lateâthough Pacino calls Dustin Hoffmanâs Oscar-nominated performance in the part âamazing.â

3. Star Wars (1977)

For years, rumors have swirled about the many actors who turned down the role of Han Solo, opening the path for Harrison Ford to make it his own. In 2013, Pacino spoke out on why he passed on the part, telling a crowd during a Q&A, âStar Wars was mine for the taking but I didnât understand the script.â

4. Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)

Speaking of classic sci-fi flicks that Pacino declined, Steven Spielberg had a host of actors on his wish list before offering the role to Richard DreyfussâSteve McQueen, Dustin Hoffman, Jack Nicholson, Gene Hackman, James Caan, and Pacino among them.

5. Slap Shot (1977)

In Al Pacino, journalist Lawrence Grobelâs extended interview-turned-semi-autobiography of the actor, Pacino cites Slap Shot as a movie he still wishes he had been able to make. âBut because George Roy Hill was doing it, I couldnât do it,â he explained.

âI should have made that movie. That was my kind of characterâthe hockey player. Paul Newman is a great actor, itâs not a matter of that. I read that script and passed it on to George Roy Hill that I wanted to talk to him about it, and all he said was, âCan he ice skate?â Thatâs all he was interested in, whether I could ice skate or not. That was a certain kind of comment. He didnât want to talk about anything else. It was like he was saying, 'What the hell, it could work with anybody.â The way in which he responded said to me he wasnât interested.â

6. Days of Heaven (1978)

In Grobelâs book, Pacino cites Days of Heaven as one of the roles that he was truly conflicted over, saying, âI love Terrence Malick, and I love the picture.â According to Peter Biskindâs Easy Riders, Raging Bulls, Dustin Hoffman also turned down the lead, which eventually became a breakthrough role for Richard Gere.

7. Coming Home (1978)

Alongside Days of Heaven, Pacino also told Grobel that saying no to the lead role in Coming Home (the role that won Jon Voight an Oscar) was a tough call. But he had his reasons. âI was hoping to make Born on the Fourth of July at that time,â he said. âIt was too close.â

8. Born on the Fourth of July (1989)

Do the math and itâs pretty obvious that the version of Born on the Fourth of July that Pacino was hoping to make back in the late 1970s was a bit different from the late 1980s film that earned Tom Cruise his first Oscar nomination. Yes, Oliver Stone was still involved, but only as the screenwriter. William Friedkin was set to direct, but when he dropped out, Pacino wanted out, too. âI had an interest in making it with Billy,â Pacino says in Al Pacino. âSo, suddenly, Friedkin is out of the pictureânow what? I wasnât going to make that movie.â

9. Kramer vs. Kramer (1979)

Pacino didnât even have to read the script for Robert Bentonâs Oscar-winning divorce drama to know it wasnât right for him. âThere were times in my life when I didnât even read what was being offered me,â he told Grobel. âSometimes I can smell something thatâs not right for me â¦ I had a feeling it was not for me â¦ I didnât feel, at this point, it would be useful.â (Dustin Hoffman won his first Oscar playing the role of Ted Kramer.)

10. Apocalypse Now (1979)

After two successful Godfather go-arounds with Francis Ford Coppola, Pacino knew enough about the directorâs work habits to know that he would not be a good fit to play Willard (Martin Sheenâs part) in Apocalypse Now. âI know what this is going to be like,â Pacino told Coppola. âYou're going to be up there in a helicopter telling me what to do, and I'm gonna be down there in a swamp for five months.â Pacino balked at the idea of five months of shooting, but the film actually took 16 months to be completed.

11. First Blood (1982)

Based on David Morrellâs 1972 book, and optioned quickly, First Blood is one of those movies that had a number of director-star configurations attached before finally making it into production. Martin Ritt wanted Paul Newman to do it, Sydney Pollack wanted Steve McQueen, and by 1975, Martin Bregman was attached with Pacino to star as John Rambo, when it was a much different movie. âPeople would have understood the character, but they wouldnât have had empathy,â original screenwriter David Rabe explained in Douglas Robinsonâs book, No Less a Man: Masculist Art in a Feminist Age. âThere is a kind of violence that excites an audience and makes them feel that itâs a lot of fun. Mine was not.â Many sources say that Pacino eventually opted out because he wanted Rambo to be more of a "madman."

12. Beverly Hills Cop (1984)

Before it became a showcase for the comedic stylings of Eddie Murphy, Beverly Hills Cop was a much edgier crime thriller that at different times was offered to Martin Scorsese and David Cronenberg to direct. Plenty of big-name actors besides Pacino turned down the role of Axel Foley, too (Mickey Rourke, Sylvester Stallone, and James Caan apparently among them).

13. Die Hard (1988)

During a freewheeling crowd Q&A in 2013, when confronted with the list of major movies that he turned down, Pacino had only this to say about Bruce Willisâ iconic role in Die Hard: âI gave that boy a career.â

14. Johnny Handsome (1989)

Though Pacino would later go on to work with director Harold Becker in Sea of Love and City Hall, in Grobelâs book, the actor explains that he first met Becker while they were developing Johnny Handsome:

âHarold and I were trying to find a third act, and we couldnât. The first half of that movie is great. That was my favorite role ever in movies. I loved the whole idea of someone whoâs been grotesque-looking and has made a life having to cope with that kind of deformity, to then have it lifted from him, and to have to cope with the world now â¦ I loved the role. Loved it. But once again, one of those roles that just go down the drain if they couldnât fix the last act. Mickey Rourke did a great job on it, but that didnât matter; the movie didnât have the finish.â

15. Snake Eyes (1998)

In 1997, Pacino was set to re-team yet again with his Scarface and Carlitoâs Way director Brian De Palma on the Nicolas Cage film Snake Eyes. Until he wasn't. On July 11, 1997, Variety reported that, âAfter months of talks between filmmaker Brian De Palma, Paramount execs, and Al Pacino about starring opposite Nicolas Cage in Snake Eyes, Pacino officially has passed. The studio now is eyeing a handful of other actors, including Gary Sinise, to star the action thriller written by David Koepp.â (Sinise did take the part.)

16. Pretty Woman (1990)
